From the podcast

From Roderick on the Line

From Palahniuk‚Äôs Haunted

‚ÄúTelling a story is how we digest what happens to us,‚Äù Mr. Whittier says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs how we digest our lives. Our experience.‚Äù

‚ÄúYou digest and absorb your life by turning it into stories,‚Äù he says.

Other events‚Äìthe ones you can‚Äôt digest‚Äìthey poison you. The worst parts of your life, those moments you can‚Äôt talk about, they rot you from the inside out.

But the stories you can digest, that you can tell‚Äìyou can take control of those past moments. You can shape them, craft them. Master them. And use them to your own good.

Those are stories as important as food.

Those are stories you can use to make people laugh or cry or sick. Or scared. To make people feel the way you felt. To help exhaust that past moment for them and for you. Until that moment is dead. Consumed. Digested. Absorbed.

Currently

Carissa says I should just roll with it. I want to be able to get an instant blood test and find out what‚Äôs wrong. Maybe this time it‚Äôs just the Summertime Blues. But overall I‚Äôm lost in a veil of Okayness. I‚Äôm ok with so much. Nothing surprises me anymore. I get frustrated with small things but the big things are all alright with me.
